title: Tricking the "Create snippet" feature into displaying the wrong filetype can lead to RCE on Slack users

profile.name: Slack
profile.about: All your team communication in one place, instantly searchable, and available wherever you go.

vulnerability_information:
Hi

**Summary**
There is an issue in Slack's `Create snippet` feature that results in filetypes being displayed incorrectly. This can lead to RCE on Slack users but only with their interaction. They need to click on the file, so let's trick Slack into making it look benign. CSV should work.

Here is a video of the entire process

{F763437}

**Steps to Reproduce**
Click the paperclip icon and select `Create new` -> `Code or text snippet` and set the title as `DATABASE-BACKUP-67298598647235234678456824634535685122342647834565469834598249829847.BAT`. The numbers do not matter. This is only to stuff characters so that the extension is hidden from the victim(s). The extension will also be hidden by tricking Slack into displaying its CSV graphic. Slack will also show the user that a .CSV file is being downloaded when it is actually a .BAT executable.

Let's populate the `Content` area with
```
START C:\Windows\NOTEPAD.EXE
goto xxx
(ﾉಥ益ಥ）ﾉ﻿ ┻━┻
:xxx
```

and the problematic character is displayed for us in Slack as a red dot between the ASCII man and the table. Click `Create Snippet`

{F763402}

The binary has been placed into the channel and erroneously displayed as a typical CSV file. 

{F763419}

If the problematic character is excluded the attack will fail.

{F763422}

Our victim clicks the "CSV file"

{F763449}

and we've owned her. 

Mobile devices are also affected

{F763427}

Please note @tehryanx found 50% of this bug and is a 50/50 collaborator. Ping me if you need anything and I will make myself available. 

Thank you,
Kevin

## Impact

RCE on Slack users. This is something that I could potentially fall for. I imagine much of Slack's userbase could as well. This issue is present on both desktop and mobile versions of the client. It is reasonable to suspect that victims could click on what appear to be benign files. There is minimal user interaction required.
vulnerability_information_html:
Hi

Summary
There is an issue in Slack's Create snippet feature that results in filetypes being displayed incorrectly. This can lead to RCE on Slack users but only with their interaction. They need to click on the file, so let's trick Slack into making it look benign. CSV should work.

Here is a video of the entire process

Steps to Reproduce
Click the paperclip icon and select Create new -> Code or text snippet and set the title as DATABASE-BACKUP-67298598647235234678456824634535685122342647834565469834598249829847.BAT. The numbers do not matter. This is only to stuff characters so that the extension is hidden from the victim(s). The extension will also be hidden by tricking Slack into displaying its CSV graphic. Slack will also show the user that a .CSV file is being downloaded when it is actually a .BAT executable.

Let's populate the Content area with

START C:\Windows\NOTEPAD.EXE
goto xxx
(ﾉಥ益ಥ）ﾉ﻿ ┻━┻
:xxx

and the problematic character is displayed for us in Slack as a red dot between the ASCII man and the table. Click Create Snippet

The binary has been placed into the channel and erroneously displayed as a typical CSV file.

If the problematic character is excluded the attack will fail.

Our victim clicks the "CSV file"

and we've owned her.

Mobile devices are also affected

Please note @tehryanx found 50% of this bug and is a 50/50 collaborator. Ping me if you need anything and I will make myself available.

Thank you,
Kevin

Impact

RCE on Slack users. This is something that I could potentially fall for. I imagine much of Slack's userbase could as well. This issue is present on both desktop and mobile versions of the client. It is reasonable to suspect that victims could click on what appear to be benign files. There is minimal user interaction required.

added_weaknesses.name: Unrestricted Upload of File with Dangerous Type

activities.message:
**Attack Scenario**

Mallory (Malicious attacker) joins Nieves’ (Inept user) Slack channel and drops malware that is crafted to look like a benign csv file.

The inept user opens Mallory’s “csv” file, and it even appears to open a legitimate csv file in his default client. This is of course by design and his personal computer is now owned. Mallory and her best friend Eve start watching.

Mallory has included a worm in her malware that propagates itself through direct messages and public channels in automated fashion. If leveraged, Nieves’ contacts could be exploited by their trust in both him as a contact and Slack as a client.

In this particular case, however, Mal refrains from triggering the worm feature. She decides to spend time studying her target. He isn’t bright, and is entertaining because of it.

Months pass.

The inept user’s personal computer has been compromised for quite some time now; and Mal has learned a lot. Most troubling to her is that Nieves works in semi-sensitive areas of government and has access to, albeit very low level, classified information. He is a confidential informant. His salary is meager but he takes what he can get.

Being inept, and downright mean at times, he selects targets that he and/or his handler dislike on a personal level. This is nothing new, but it’s enough to spook Mal and Eve. The inept user and his handler have virtually no ethical oversight and take advantage of it. In some cases even just to harass people who have made them look foolish. Even going as far as harassing a target’s family members in acts of desperation. This is to probe and to bait what is ideally an illegal response.

Mallory pieces this information together and panics. Eve, out of character, convinces her to remotely disable the Virus. Mal now understands that if her victim discovered that he’d been under attack that he would’ve contacted federal law-enforcement with an old but trusty direct line.

She wipes her computer. Multiple passes. She feels that she has dodged a bullet, and that she too old for this stuff anyway. That and much of the hacker community is rather toxic. With this epiphany, she decides to use her powers for good.

She joins HackerOne.

Not only because it’s the moral thing to do, but also because a large percentage of people in the infosec community are confidential informants. Why risk it?

She’s reborn.

Mallory knows that quitting while she is ahead is not the same as quitting, and goes on to assist the government in areas that are unrelated to petty domestic law-enforcement. She lives happily ever after.

The inept user is later hit by a bus while crossing the street and struggling to figure out a simple GPS app. He dies as he lived; using other people’s software because he is unable to program his own.

Attack Scenario

Mallory (Malicious attacker) joins Nieves’ (Inept user) Slack channel and drops malware that is crafted to look like a benign csv file.

The inept user opens Mallory’s “csv” file, and it even appears to open a legitimate csv file in his default client. This is of course by design and his personal computer is now owned. Mallory and her best friend Eve start watching.

Mallory has included a worm in her malware that propagates itself through direct messages and public channels in automated fashion. If leveraged, Nieves’ contacts could be exploited by their trust in both him as a contact and Slack as a client.

In this particular case, however, Mal refrains from triggering the worm feature. She decides to spend time studying her target. He isn’t bright, and is entertaining because of it.

Months pass.

The inept user’s personal computer has been compromised for quite some time now; and Mal has learned a lot. Most troubling to her is that Nieves works in semi-sensitive areas of government and has access to, albeit very low level, classified information. He is a confidential informant. His salary is meager but he takes what he can get.

Being inept, and downright mean at times, he selects targets that he and/or his handler dislike on a personal level. This is nothing new, but it’s enough to spook Mal and Eve. The inept user and his handler have virtually no ethical oversight and take advantage of it. In some cases even just to harass people who have made them look foolish. Even going as far as harassing a target’s family members in acts of desperation. This is to probe and to bait what is ideally an illegal response.

Mallory pieces this information together and panics. Eve, out of character, convinces her to remotely disable the Virus. Mal now understands that if her victim discovered that he’d been under attack that he would’ve contacted federal law-enforcement with an old but trusty direct line.

She wipes her computer. Multiple passes. She feels that she has dodged a bullet, and that she too old for this stuff anyway. That and much of the hacker community is rather toxic. With this epiphany, she decides to use her powers for good.

She joins HackerOne.

Not only because it’s the moral thing to do, but also because a large percentage of people in the infosec community are confidential informants. Why risk it?

She’s reborn.

Mallory knows that quitting while she is ahead is not the same as quitting, and goes on to assist the government in areas that are unrelated to petty domestic law-enforcement. She lives happily ever after.

The inept user is later hit by a bus while crossing the street and struggling to figure out a simple GPS app. He dies as he lived; using other people’s software because he is unable to program his own.

@owlmerta thank you for the submission!  

Be sure to check out the promotion news regarding our bounty increase for High and Critical severities over the next 90 days.

https://www.hackerone.com/blog/slack-increases-bounty-minimums-next-90-days

Best,
Branden

activities.message: Hey @owlmerta - The team is still working on this, thanks for your patience!
activities.markdown_message: Hey @owlmerta - The team is still working on this, thanks for your patience!

activities.message:
Hi @owlmerta 

I believe a fix should now be in place for this issue.  Can you verify that that issue is correctly fixed on your end?
activities.markdown_message:

Let me double check internally about disclosure and get back to you.

activities.message: Not a blog or press guy. This bug was fun, simple and a vote for https://github.com/minimaxir/big-list-of-naughty-strings/blob/master/blns.txt
activities.markdown_message: Not a blog or press guy. This bug was fun, simple and a vote for https://github.com/minimaxir/big-list-of-naughty-strings/blob/master/blns.txt

activities.message:
@brandenjordan actually if journalists were curious I'd have no issue chitchatting with them in a way that wasn't damaging to any corporate brands. I like making money..

Anyway, can we fully disclose?

activities.message:
Hi Kevin,

So we have approval to disclose as you originally mentioned to https://github.com/minimaxir/big-list-of-naughty-strings/blob/master/blns.txt

I'll need to chase down approvals for something broader.  

Best,
Branden

activities.message: That's a list someone else made. It's just where I happened to find the glitchy chr. It's uncommon to find RCE with those. Want to fully disclose for that reason among others. I see other sensitive disclosures with higher bounties.

activities.message:
Hey @mcsheehan 

Since disclosure approval has been finalized, I'll go ahead and "Request" it again from our side and you should good to go.  Please let me know if you have any problems or questions.

Thanks.
